author: The_Goodest_Dude
body:
I don’t do a lot of research besides what’s in the news. Instead I invest in things I use or know a lot of other people use, or what a lot of companies use. 

I’m invested in FB because I have a Facebook, use it a lot, and I know that Facebook is more then just a social media website. They’re tryng to rebrand as such so I invested. I have near 28% return for the year. They’re at a 52 week high so I’ll probably be selling at least some of my stock. 

I want a Tesla really bad, I’m starting to get into electric and alternative energy. But I know TSLA is all over the place and I’m to afraid to jump in atm, especially since I don’t know a lot. Instead I looked into solar energy and noticed there’s really two major solar companies that are really developing quick. So I invested in ENPH and have a 16% return. 

But I also have a portion of my portfolio in mutual funds like FNCMX which is what I first started using when I invested and got a 401k for the first time. It follows the NASDAQ but there’s also funds for the S&P. If you really want to start putting your money in the mutual funds are a relatively safe and consistent choice. Read a few articles about mutual funds and you’ll understand they’re pretty simple to grasp. There’s also funds that follow different regions, international, specific market, etc. Read up on ETFs as well. 

The only real ‘research’ I do is read the links and sources other people post in r/stocks when they talk about something I’m familiar with.

Edit: I’m pretty young and can risk being a little risky with what I’m doing. And I’m constantly learning and reading or watching videos as I go.

author: LeonardoRafaell
body:
This is an overlooked part of the market. Most ppl focus on the big boys. But i like small caps.  Here's  3 for you:

1) lattice semiconductor LSCC.  quality is off the charts for their work. Company turned itself around in the last few years. It has been on a nice run, so maybe  a bit over 2B mc now.  Great growth ahead with 5g, AI, autonomous vehicles coming and needing quality chips and chip equipment.  

2) Digital Turbine APPS   . very rare company.  No debt. Software play that installs people's apps on phones in the box, remotely. They have partnerships with samsung, htc, etc....new innovative products coming soon. Still under 1B mc

3) Enphase Energy ENPH. Another high growth small cap. Will be mid cap pretty soon. Enphase is legitimately dominating solar micro inverters. They are the shovel of the solar gold rush.

Runner up: Endava, plc. DAVA. british tech consulting firm. Huge growth already and just getting started.


*also a word of advice,  avoid crypto and cannabis

author: hugsfunny
body:
ENPH, SEDG, and QCLN for clean energy. The growth isn’t going to slow down. Even if the economy stalls, I would expect stimulus packages to target this sector. 

FIW and CQW for water. Climate change play. 

NOK for reasons mentioned elsewhere in this thread. 

APHA as the most financially sound MJ company. 

NUAN and CRNC for voice AI. I see massive room for growth with the former as EMRs expand globally. Also, I’ve used Dragon and it’s exceptional. Much better than Alexa or Google in my experience. They have a large moat in the medical industry and will continue to collect subscription dollars for many years to come. I expect the latter to eventually be acquired by an auto company or FANG as an asset to help compete against TSLA. 

SBUX as they continue to push into new markets. The dividend isn’t terrible in the meantime. 

ITHUF and TCNNF if Bernie is elected. They will make a huge run if US closes in on MJ legalization. 

WELL and OHI for REITs. Old people need care. Inflexible and growing demand with the aging population. 

GOOGL, MSFT, V, DAL, WM and MDT are my plays for lower risk growth. These companies continue to crush expectations and have solid moats.

author: lobster_johnson
body: There's the danger that a Chinese manufacturer could flood the market with much cheaper products, which is what Citron predicted last year. Not sure how ENPH has avoided this so far; they have a solid reputation, but do they have any kind of competitive moat (other than, perhaps, tariffs)? Apparently Huawei being forced out of the market was a big boost.

author: DieOnYourFeat
body:
I have an income generating account that I won't touch unless one of its constituents stops paying a dividend. as to my other accounts I am considering doing a pairs trade where I go long MSFT and short QQQQ. Another pairs trade I am considering is shorting a solar ETF but staying long ENPH. Finally I might well write leaps against my entire ENPH position as they are set up right now to gain 41% a year even if the stock doesn't gain a nickel which should offset a substantial decline.  

So basically stay fully invested with some hedges.

author: Known-Appeal
body:
I have ENPH products on my solar roof. I'm a happy customer. Unlike SEDG 's central inverter, ENPH has less loss and connects panels in series, not parallel, so one shady spot doesn't nerf your whole system.

It's been a great ride. I have 50 shares purchased at $17 each.

author: DieOnYourFeat
body:
Beyond the usual suspects I would say ACAD, ENPH, and KALA, PRVB

Pretty sure ACAD will get bought out this year at between $80 and $100 and looking at the call activity verifies that to me. Baker Brothers get this stuff right most of the time. 

ENPH because they are still early in their growth, coming out with new products, leading technology, would not be surprised at all to see this at 70 by end of year. My biggest holding by far. 

KALA is more of a gamble but I feel it is asymmetrical risk in my favor. They could easily go to 15 in the next 3 months depending on pending FDA actions, and their biotechnology is applicable to more products. some speculate it could become $100 stock in a matter of a few years certainly if it pops to 15 I will not be selling.

PRVB - I am invested in this one fairly deeply but it worries me the most. The reason it worries me is I cannot figure out why it is trading as low as it is given their pipeline and where they are in process with it. Depending on what happens in the next two months this could be a $5 or $50 stock. Maybe more if someone like NORD takes them out.

body:
My risk tolerance is far below what buying SPWR would require. I'd buy them when profitability is within a year, and there would still be plenty of room for growth.

I'm buying ENPH and SEDG. It's the tech at the heart of it all. It's where the intrinsic value lays. They are the relatively indispensable focusing point, compared to all the generators, installers, retailers etc. They do one thing and do it well.

author: Viscoden
body:
I hold ENPH, TERP (might be getting purchased by Brookfield), ICLN, and VSLR. I also watch MANY solar/clean energy stocks, but I haven't I around to buying yet.  TAN would probably be a good alternative to ICLN. 

Half related, I don't think it's a bad idea to put a small portion in to Uranium. I have some LEU and am following some other Uranium stocks as well. While there are parts of uranium that are bad for the environment, it also has lots of potential if we can solve the negative from it.

I myself would also consider investing in certain tech/ utility companies as "doing good". I'm in very heavy on XEL, and I have been for quite a long time. MSFT recently has vowed to be carbon negative by 2030, and I have been slowly acquiring shares when I can.

author: Extrosity
body: I would definitely recommend solaredge over enph, while they do have the micro inverter market, solar edge is massively booming. I work in solar distribution and we have been seeing 16-20 week lead times on solar edge, all large installers are swapping to them. In the last they had a high fail rate due to their displays but this has been fixed. In q1/q2 they are releasing their new inverter series that will have EV charging on every inverter. The market growth potential of solar edge is in a much better place.

author: attirer
body:
BEP.UN is a good investment but after a huge run in 2019 its price is also very high right now. I hold the parent company, BAM.A, rather than the subsidiary because I’m interested in gains from all of the related companies (BIP.UN, BPY.UN, BBU.UN) and I’m not drawn to the high dividend yield.

AQN and NEE (US-listed) are two other good companies but I don’t follow them as closely so I don’t know what their prices are like right now.

SEDG is an amazing solar tech company that I hold that’s also benefited from a huge run in 2019. It gets compared a lot to ENPH but if you’re concerned with fundamentals then SEDG is the clear winner.

author: HowToBeAwkward_
body:
It would be a stock split. Lots of ppl would flock to FB before that split date deadline. Splits historically appreciate both split stocks to higher combined valuations. There’s numerous examples from last year (EBAY/PPL, HP/HPE, HLT/PK & HGV.  

Secondary point- antitrust takes forever
